Parents can start by disconnecting from their own social networking addictions and not diving into their cell phones every 3 minutes. Leave work and the world behind! Parents need to genuinely interact with their children, otherwise what's the point of taking the family somewhere new if everyone is simply bringing along their own 'entertainment bubble'? Take children to where they can really interact with real people or nature, not the plasticised, calorific worlds of ghastly theme parks and the like. For city kids especially, how about a farm vacation, where they can see how food is raised?

I admire vegans because they've chosen a challenging lifestyle requiring a lot of work, discipline and attention. I tried it briefly because I'm so repulsed by the idea of eating a dead animal. It's so primitive. But after a few weeks of veganism I craved dairy foods so much that I couldn't think straight. So I gave in, and drink milk and eat cheese and eggs. And when I have an overwhelming desire for some meat I eat just a very small amount. Judging from my experience, I'm left with the feeling that humans should perhaps evolve biologically, slowly, and wean themselves from meat over many years. Accent plant foods and cut meat servings to half, for starters. I do believe there will come a time, perhaps 100 years from now, when humans will look back on meat eating with disgust.

I'm all for broad education. I'm a product of it. As a teacher and professor I spent my professional life in it,. And in my college planning practice, I've guided most of my students towards it. But Mr. Hamed is exactly right when he says, "If our goal is to lift students from poverty to high-paying programming jobs, this school's curriculum is admirable." It may or may not produce the next Steve Jobs - we can argue about how geniuses arise some other time - but good vocational education lifts students who otherwise might flounder and founder into jobs that provide them with pride, stability and a good living. I wish more schools did as much.

I live in Florida which makes it very difficult to restore civil rights to felons. The laws have become a new form of Jim Crow to prevent minorities from voting. Your chance of becoming a felon is much greater if you are dark of skin hue. Or a different ethnicity than being a WASP. Time to end this persecution of people We need to reform our justice system.. After release all voting rights should be restored . If a non violent conviction even the right to own fire arms should be restored.

As a school librarian who enjoys working with our local public library system, I think there is a lot to be said for looking at ways for the two to work together more closely to best serve our students, not as a cost-saving measure. Can we deliver better service and aid student achievement by joining up more effectively? But while there is overlap in the goals of public and school libraries, they have a different focus in their staffing and services. In addition, as teachers are asked to do more and more, a school librarian is able to support THEIR training needs and those of students to provide instruction and resources that match their curricular needs. The school librarian provides a fantastic value, reaching every single child and staff member in a school - every program, teacher, administrator, and students of every background and ability are served. Talk about bang for your buck!

I drove the Leaf last week. It's a super little car that will be launch electric travel for the masses. For those who claim it will run up electric prices by burning more oil, they just don't realize that coal burning electric plants never shut down. One can't save electricity. You don't turn the plant off at night just because demand is low. That's why charging cars at night makes so much sense. Secondly, if you have solar in your home, you're already providing the grid with additional clean power. I hope that green technology will go hand-in-hand with the Leaf and other electric vehicles. And lastly, the average person drives less than one hundred miles a day. This giant fear of getting stuck is just that -- fear. It's amazing how fear stops progress. Be bold people. Let's get off oil and free our politics by making it a little easier to make peace.

I couldn't agree more, that parents should have a choice. it's america after all. HOWEVER, the school districts then must be allowed to reject the attendance of those unvaccinated students. Let the anti-vaxers start their own private schools that their children can attend, and die from preventable diseases to their hearts content. (and although that is cruel, it is only cruel because that is exactly what will happen to them!)

There is absolutly nothing wrong with a vegan diet in any of the stages of life, there are many cases of life long vegans from all over the world who are very healthy so i will rule out genetics and ancestry roots to what we can tolerate or not. the problem with why some people think it is inadequate is because they do not know what vegans can or cannot eat, and then there is a lot of misinformation from people that want to protect their own interest of meat eating telling others that it is dangerous! if you plan well your diet and know what you are eating then it is as simple as pie and anybody can benefit from a strict vegetrian diet. it is obvious that if all you eat is lettuce it can be very dangerous for you and most probably fatal, the same can be said if all you eat is red meat with red meat! however if you eat a wide variety of plant based foods your body can aquire all of the essential nutrients that it needs to thrive.

Whatever the fate of the majority of women's colleges, the best such as Wellesley should survive. Why not have choice. I am unaware of any remaining, highly selective men's colleges, but choice should be preserved for women, especially if they can enroll in courses at nearby co-ed universities that are equally selective. Perhaps among the little Ivies, one or two should have remained all male. I went to a university that from the outset was to be co-ed (ok it took a few years while it raised money for a women's dorm). More than a few of my female contemporaries went on to excel in medical schools, law schools, and graduate school. I never noticed, however, any particular women's point of view in class; just excellence.

"... the development of a ratings system is a complex and massive - but not impossible - undertaking": Well, this gets two out of three right. "I commend President Obama and his administration for tackling this difficult endeavor": Being nice to them might be a smart career move, but it isn't going to do SUNY any good. "I ... encourage my colleagues across the country to seek out an active role in the process." The administration has already told your colleagues how much it values their input; you echo that message when you write "whether we like it or not."

Easy access to relevant and accurate information is a cornerstone in our democracy. How can we not have specialists (aka librarians) who find, catalog, index, and protect the information used by all of us? We all frequently rely on specialists - medical, technical, financial, etc. - for the best information and advice. In this exploding universe of digital information, let's encourage our academic and governmental decision makers to fully realize the critical and specialized value that librarians provide to patrons of all ages.

Yes. Thank you. Except: > And for those who develop a substance dependency, marijuana regulation will generate revenue to support drug treatment for those who need and want it. That's the reactive approach. Resources do need to go to treatment. but also to prior education. The fact that people do not recognize alcohol as a far more dangerous drug than marijuana is more proof than we'd ever need that we are making rules without having even a basic understanding of the science or sociology of addiction.

My understanding is that college athletic teams were started to teach leadership, discipline and teamwork to students. With the introduction of the athletic scholarship schools went down the slippery slope of bringing in kids who either were not prepared to do collegiate work or had no serious intent of gaining a degree. Instead of being a benefit to the academic student body, athletics became something more geared toward the fan in the stands and the alumni association- students be damned. What Spelman has done is right in so many ways. The new program will benefit all students, will open new friendships among students and will give students valuable training in how to maintain a healthy body for a lifetime. Truth be told, intramural athletics can provide the same benefits to the student body as varsity and can engage many more students at a far lower price. The fitness program is wonderful.

Income is income and should be taxed as the least harmful of all taxes. Eliminate property tax, but tax all income at the same graduated rates. Currently, there is no benefit in savings with interest rates at .3%. Investors should be encouraged to invest in capital projects or improvements, or donate to philanthropic groups by taxing idle income.

As one who has not a single dream in 70 years of life despite many therapists asserting that I certainly had dreams and just stubbornly redefined them as something else; I would welcome the idea of scripting dreams! Having attempted directed dreaming, directed meditation, countless visualization methods, and the like; I'll accept the notion of dreaming, but without the personal experience I must concede that I am like the blind man wondering on the nature of a sunrise! So all you script writers; please script away!!

As one who has not a single dream in 70 years of life despite many therapists asserting that I certainly had dreams and just stubbornly redefined them as something else; I would welcome the idea of scripting dreams! Having attempted directed dreaming, directed meditation, countless visualization methods, and the like; I'll accept the notion of dreaming, but without the personal experience I must concede that I am like the blind man wondering on the nature of a sunrise! So all you script writers; please script away!!

#21 is right so far as this is a legal issue re. employee/employer. But enough's enough. Let people speak their minds. These are tough times; there's lot's to be upset about. Less repression and less what's essentially sanctimonious PR by the complainers might do us more good in the long run. The point of a right to free speech is precisely that some people's opinions about important things are bound to offend (i.e., really offend) some other people (and draw negative attention). So, we (the right thinking one's among us) are offended, uncomfortable, squirming; get over it.

The first are broad patents on isolated DNA sequences, which cover the gene in something very close to its natural form. " This is an example of something that shouldn't happen. What the body creates, even if someone extracts it, shouldn't be patentable. The DNA sequence is there for anyone to find with the proper technology. It's like picking fruit off the tree and saying I've "discovered" fruit. This is crazy, but then we know that the ROBBER COURT will back business to the hilt. The Supremes are now one big legal joke, and I hope in the future we can manage to pass some legislation to limit SCOTUS judges to 10 years or less. Perhaps the term length of the president that offers them up for sale.

Ask how many schools are importing foreign students...... Yes, getting international students is nice, promotes American values, brings money into the country, etc. etc., but let's ask a nasty question: if an applicant is coming from abroad and will pay full freight for whatever tuition bill the university hands him, what incentive does any school (state, private, whatever) have to create financially livable conditions for students and provide financial help to American kids to avoid a debt-filled future? We have not had enough of a debate on this question.

I, too, am a liberal who is finding it harder and harder to hate Wal-Mart. First they streamlined operations, then they brought big changes to the way they heat and cool their buildings, even bringing in renewables. Then they brought their influence to bear on the farms which sell to them, requiring that they get smarter about their use of fertilizer and water (economical and environmental benefits). Now they're changing the quality of the foods they sell us, with immense implications for the nation's health and health care. All without a government mandate: conservatives should be dancing in the aisles, alongside us liberals, in encouraging such enlightened self-interest.

Yes. Thank you. Except: > And for those who develop a substance dependency, marijuana regulation will generate revenue to support drug treatment for those who need and want it. That's the reactive approach. Resources do need to go to treatment. but also to prior education. The fact that people do not recognize alcohol as a far more dangerous drug than marijuana is more proof than we'd ever need that we are making rules without having even a basic understanding of the science or sociology of addiction.

I think that teachers should teach what there assinged to teach. Teachers have gone to school for this and this is what they do for a living. So they probably know what they're talking about. If you dont like what teachers are teaching in public schools then you should probably enroll your kid in a private school

We should have consumption (sales or VAT) taxes and capital gains taxes should be 50 percent declining one percent per quarter reaching zero in 12 1/2 years. The corporate tax rate should be zero, and C Corp. earnings should be taxed like S Corp. earnings. That would eliminate the cause of cash hoards in Corp. treasuries, and provide more liquidity. Most current deductions other than catastrophic loss should be eliminated. Charitable deductions should be more limited if not eliminated, especially for organizations that propound political positions (churches that mention politics, policy think tanks, and all political advocacy groups). But look out for the European outcome with high VAT, income, dividend, and capital gain taxes like Germany where too large a share of GNP is run through government accounts. We should have very little reliance on income taxes as they discourage both work and business. Those mega yachts, and mega dwellings are a simptom of the foolish tax laws we have now.

. Do alcohol and marijuana affect some users negatively? Absolutely. Should minors be allowed to legally consume either one? No. But the war on drugs is a failure. All it does is promote violence and enrich big time drug dealers and the utterly corrupt interdiction apparatus both in the U.S. and abroad. I don't endorse the use of either marijuana or alcohol. But making them illegal protects no one.

We have to start somewhere and this is as good a place as any. We are all participants in a huge public experiment: first, when it came to large scale food production, then to packaged foods and fast foods, and now to mass produced balanced nutrition. I applaud Walmart for taking the lead. I hope they also restructure their store configurations so you find the good stuff in the front and have to dig for the sinful stuff in the back. Think back to the colorful markets of the past (and still in the Caribbean and Pacific islands as well as throughout Europe) and the popular street markets of today (Union Square in NYC and the waterfront markets in Seattle) and perhaps you'll be writing a success story soon. If not, try and try again. It took time to do it, hopefully it will take less to undo it. Thanks for taking the lead Walmart.

When a couple decides to have children, the children become an integral part of the family and should not be excluded from family adventures unless a child has so severe a disability that he or she cannot go. We rarely took vacations, but when we did it was as a family. Now that our children are grown and all moved away, we seldom see them, so those together times have become even more precious. Children grow up so fast--enjoy them as much as you can. Carve out time for yourselves by enforcing an early bedtime for the offspring.

I, too, qualify for Irish citizenship. The only problem I have with it is my shared experiences are American. I am more like italian catholic jewish indian bostonians houstonians than anyone in Ireland, though Ireland be the source of wit and stoicism, etc. When I traveled extensively, I felt it wrong to be 'Irish.' I do love things Irish- music, poetry etc--but I am American. Our citizenship is precious. So, is Irish citizenship. Apart from vanity, I had and have no reason to have the Irish passport, nor does Ms Bachmann, a would be President

edthefed is right. Shared values is not a sufficient reason to form an alliance. An alliance should also be mutually beneficial. Allying with Israel is not in the US interest. The problems that Israel helps the US with are mostly issues that are problems for the US only because we are allied with Israel. We should distance ourselves from both Israel and the Palestinians and pursue normal relations with other Arab countries like Tunisia and Oman on their own merits, not as part of a worldview that makes everything revolve around the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. That conflict is central to Israel, but not to the US. Or, rather, the only thing that makes that conflict important for the the US is the alliance with Israel; ending the alliance ends the issue as a central problem for the US.

Palestine should be recognized as a state when its inhabitants become more interested in statehood than in destroying a neghboring state; or as Golda put it a few decades ago, "...when (they) begin to love their children only half as much as they hate (us) . .."

In december i was was working graveyard shift and started feeling a loss of function in my right arm. Looked it up using my left hand and was directed to a stroke web site next thing I did was have the shift lead call 911. By the time the paramedics arrived I'd lost feeling on all of my right side. Got to the er and was stabilized and with a few hours of tests the diagnosis the web gave me was confirmed. Glad that resource was there

Of course we need more secure borders. We must decide at the very beginning if we are going to have borders or if we are not. If the answer is that we must have borders, then those borders must be secure, or they might as well just open them to the world. Not an easy decision, but one which must be made. According to most estimates, there are 11 million undocumented immigrants in our country. Some estimates are even higher. If we have, so far, been unable to locate. identify and detain those 11 million people, how will we find and detain the next 11 million after this current group is processed and given what they have been seeking? And the next 11 million after that? And the next? And the next?

There should be no exeptions from vaccinations with the exception of valid medical exemptions i.e. an individual with a serious allergy to the vaccine for example an egg alergy in the case of the flu vaccine. Asside from that demonstratable allergy no exemptions for either personal belief or religion should be entertained. If I had my way vaccinations would be a part of a single payer national health system providing universal care. The private sector has proved itself to be incompetent to provide modern health care and need to step asside.

Arguments such as these frustrate me. When Dr. Evins comes up with a solution to the downsides of keeping marijuana illegal (which any 16-year old in the country can find now without any difficulty whatsoever), not limited to the money flowing to drug cartels, the violence associated with illegal distribution, the racial and ethnic differences in lives lost, ruined and diminished due to disparities in criminal justice processing, (should I go on?), I'll take state control and distribution any day of the week. If she wants to whine about the marketing to children, tell her to go whine to all those free-market Republicans who believe that the markets can do no harm. Maybe they should be required to take the Hippocratic Oath.

As one who has not a single dream in 70 years of life despite many therapists asserting that I certainly had dreams and just stubbornly redefined them as something else; I would welcome the idea of scripting dreams! Having attempted directed dreaming, directed meditation, countless visualization methods, and the like; I'll accept the notion of dreaming, but without the personal experience I must concede that I am like the blind man wondering on the nature of a sunrise! So all you script writers; please script away!!

I agree that parents (and the kids, once they're old enough--say, 16) should have the right to opt in or out of SOME vaccinations--namely, ones for diseases that are hard to spread. Hepatitis B? HPV? Be my guest--that choice only affects your family, because those are not diseases your kid can spread at school, on the bus, etc. But no one without a medical exemption should be able to opt out of vaccinations against HIGHLY CONTAGIOUS, very dangerous diseases like German measles, pertussis/whooping cough, mumps (which can leave little boys permanently infertile), etc. Measles can live on surfaces like classroom desks and the metal handles people hold in buses for several hours. Nobody has the right to expose complete strangers to devastating diseases that are so easy to prevent.

As a cancer survivor (14 years in remission after an aggressive lymphoma treated with Chemotherapy and monoclonal antibody therapy) I am happy to say that I made very extensive use of the Google during my treatment. It obviously doesn't replace or 'outrank' my specialists, but I found it was a big help in educating me and filling in background info on my situation and the treatment options that were being recommended. I believe researching options online helped me to ask better questions and ultimately made me a lot more comfortable with the treatment plan my doctors recommended. In most cases, the information I found online agreed with what the docs were telling me. I found that to be very comforting because I didn't just feel like I was taking everything the docs said on blind faith and at face value. In at least 2 cases, the questions I asked did lead to changes in my treatment plan.

I compete in the Miss America pageant system. In two of my interviews last year, I was asked how I failed and how I overcame that failure. Not only does the Miss America Organization fuel confidence in young women and provides scholarship, but it prepares us for real-world job interviews, public speaking, and brings out the servants' heart in all of us. A huge part of the Miss America Organization is community service. Since 2007, when we first partnered with Children's Miracle Network, the women competing in the organization have raised over $8 million JUST for that one charity. Aside from that, we all have a personal platform that we are advocates for including prevention of diseases, standing up against bullying and breaking stereotypes and barriers that are presented against women. I can't speak for every pageant system, but Miss America is a non-profit organization that is made up by dedicated volunteers. Some incredible women have gone through that organization to go on to incredible careers and futures and a lot of them credit their success to the journey and experience they gained from competing in this program.

Of course their salaries should be raised. But this should be separated from the discussion about legality. Salaries should be raised and only legal workers should be employed. Its really a no brainer. And any discussion about only Mexicans being prepared to do this work so it has to be illegal is completely disingenuous.

Just over 70 years ago we allied with Josef Stalin to defeat Nazi Germany. stalin's Soviet Union was at least as bad as the Assad regime is now. ISIS might not yet be the existential threat posed by the Axis powers but it is heading that way. Point being that we should do whatever is necessary short of WMD to defeat this evil. Even if it means cooperating with Assad whose regime, while brutal, poses no threat to the US.

I like this initiative. Wal-Mart is doing a good thing for its customers. Wal-Mart definitely deserves praise for using its power for good for once. Wal-Mart has caused many small businesses to go under and has had serious labor issues over the years. It really owes its customers and employees for their loyalty (even if, in some situations, Wal-Mart is the only game in town) and this healthy food initiative is a wonderful way to start.

As a high school teacher of English for the past thirty five years, I believe we still need to teach students to have ideas that are supported with factual information. Notice, I said factual information. It is sad in our world today when the supporters of finding real information, librarians, have been systematically cut from school budgets. Many librarians have crossed the bridge to finding legitimate information in the digital world as well as printed materials. Only, now that we need verification of information, do we find a shortage of personnel who can teach that skill.

Kids already can and do use marijuana. The law isn't going to make a major difference here. It is hard to argue that marijuana should be illegal when alcohol and tobacco, both more harmful substances, are legal and widely promoted. And in your hysterical attempt to portray marijuana as the demon weed you ignore the fact that the arrests and violence that accompany marijuana use and sales do more harm than the drug actually does. I'm concerned about the fact that many kids don't understand that marijuana is harmful. Not only does it lead to demotivation in some, it now appears that it can permanenty lower the IQ of a teenage user by some 9 points. But alcohol also damages the teenage brain. What we need here is education, not prohibition, and a ban on advertising and promotion -- something we should have for alcohol and tobacco as well, but do not.

Just wish them both well and give them a fair chance. Princess Diana's verve and spirit made her a superstar, and she used her celebrity to do real good in the world. I hope this will happen with William and Kate as well.

The author's last sentence actually magpies a strong case for women's colleges. CoEd colleges are not generally "...gender-integrated places, where no one is excluded and both sexes learn how to respect, collaborate with and lead each other through shared experience." This is a nice fantasy but it is not reality. I was fortunate to go to an women's college in a curriculum where male students had to come to our turf. So I had the best of both worlds - the opportunity to study with men but in an environment where women's opinions and observations were honored because it was a women's college. PS. Having just finished "I am Charlotte Simmons" by Tom Wolfe, I think we have made the mistake of thinking that age is the equivalent of the emotional maturity necessary to live together and study together in a mutually beneficial way. If anything, we should have more segregation of the sexes through the college years - not less.

Without relevant travel, learning a language neither occurs nor is relevant to later life. Let's require a semester abroad or gap year to go with that language requirement. And let's fund it so it is not only the rich who benefit.

We recently visited a no-tipping restaurant in Athens, Ohio -- Casa Nueva -- and I was surprised how liberating it felt with no need to tip. We just paid the stated price for our meal, period. How simple! And I felt good that the waitstaff (and behind-the-scenes cooks and busboys) were making a good wage. I've waited tables and I know the thrill of big tips, but as a diner I now vastly prefer the flat-rate, no-tip system. End tips, raise my prices and pay the waitstaff a great wage, please!

Don't parents also deserve to have a choice with regards to wether or not they feed their children? Just because science and history have proven that forcing my daughter to sustain herself on just a cracker and piece of lettuce each day, that doesn't mean that I should be deprived of my ability to choose the life my daughter will live so it conforms to my personal beliefs about body image. Maybe god tells me that my daughter is evil if she weighs over 100 lbs, or maybe it's my social circle that believes that a skeletal figure is healthy and beautiful. The point is, it should be MY choice, because that's what freedom is about. And hey, if she isn't strong enough to live with the lifestyle I choose, that's her problem.

I agree with the poster who said there's no one-size approach to this question. My ideal solution would be to take a vacation without the kids ~and~ the husband. Of course, you don't know my family. You think that's heartless and selfish until I explain that I live with the exasperating reality of a husband with mental illness and five step-kids two of whom also have mental illness, who spend the majority of their time with a mom who has very low standards for her own behavior let alone theirs. Yeah, I know- it's my bed, I'll lie in it. But a couple nights to lie in it alone would be nice.

Battle Hymn of a Feminist Mom: schoolwork doesn't always come first because things are often learned outside the classroom, an A- is a terrific grade, the kids are where they are in Math not 2 years ahead, activities only to win a medal? Pshaw! Failure is a necessary experience. (See Silicon Valley) But.... disrespect women, gays and people from communities of color?...then the warrior hammer comes down.

Go, Nina! After years as a vegan (and the dangerously low cholesterol levels that came with it), I couldn't agree more that humans are omnivores by design. No doubt many of us don't get enough veggies, but that's not justification for ignoring our ancestry and anatomy/physiology. As a Naturopathic Doctor with years of clinical and research experience, I have a sound understanding of human nutrition. The bottom line is that there exists no sound argument that humans are designed to be strict plant eaters. In fact, everything from our teeth to the other end of our digestive tract suggests that we are, and have always been, omnivores. If we were meant to be vegans, we would not need to supplement our diets with the various nutrients that a vegan diet is deficient in.

I would support the idea of class-based vs. race-based admission affirmative action in college admissions. If it is true that race is a large factor in economic disadvantage and denied opportunities, then class based AA will address that. Otherwise, it creates more discrimination based on race, and assumptions (fair or not) that a student got in only because of race. While Texas does many things wrong, their 10% rule for the top two universities generally addresses this. It is very transparent, and everyone knows the expectation going in. The AA idea based on race is in itself racist, since it assumes that race alone is a factor in ability and achievement. As an example, if my child was 1/16 Chickasaw instead of 1/32 Chickasaw, he could have received a full ride. It has nothing to do with character, academic ability, or income. The whole thing is a big game designed to make the universities look good on paper to meet whatever goals they need to get funding. I don't see it helping the students and parents who are struggling to get in and pay the tuition to stay in.

This is where I really like Israel. B/c they act on intel. with airstrikes, maybe they tell us, but it always hits the news. They've gone into Syria multiple times bombed a moving target and came back home. They ACT. Why us, why now, why not the EU or NATO, or the Arab League??? No, Assad is done. He's vicious and deplorable. Appeal to the UN to give Israel the territory they already control, the Golan Heights. Appeal to the UN and possibly act with others, see above, to formally give the Kurds the State they already have control over; something the Europeans forgot about in the early 20th Century. Aid the Israelis and the Kurds, not Assad.

All of my children have been, or are being home schooled through high school. The oldest will be graduating from college this year, the recepient of a few scholarships. Home schooling is not easy, and it is not for everyone. This being said, I have to agree with those who have posted that all of us benefit from the public school system, and must fund it via our taxes. We should demand more of our schools so that our communities' children will get the education that they should to be productive members of society.

I would go even further. Making all beaches public, and requiring public access to all beaches WITHOUT the beach-goer having to pay a fee to get to the beach. FOr instance, the NOrthern California coast is spectacular, north of San Francisco. I find it offensive to come to a place like Sea Ranch, and find that all the pullouts along highway 1 in this area, from where one can walk to the beach, require you to pay a fee to park. So, unless you are traveling the highway without a car, there is no way to access the beach at Sea Ranch without paying a fee. THis should be forbidden. In my view, we should also prevent people from being able to buy land within a certain distance of the water in areas that remain undeveloped, in order to better preserve these undeveloped areas.

The debate seems limited to certain medical websites. What really gives good options is the reading of research articles themselves. Yes, it requires more education and some knowledge of anatomy, neurology, etc. But those who can do it, can find doctors and researchers willing to treat them. And they can manage their problems much better than if they relied on a single doctor. And don't forget, the US is almost the last resort for medical advice. Big pharma here is unfettered and excludes supplements and unpatentable drugs. Much research is going on elsewhere in the world. You must read those articles, and act accordingly. Read Swiss, Italian, Armenia, Turksih researchers!

We have to start somewhere and this is as good a place as any. We are all participants in a huge public experiment: first, when it came to large scale food production, then to packaged foods and fast foods, and now to mass produced balanced nutrition. I applaud Walmart for taking the lead. I hope they also restructure their store configurations so you find the good stuff in the front and have to dig for the sinful stuff in the back. Think back to the colorful markets of the past (and still in the Caribbean and Pacific islands as well as throughout Europe) and the popular street markets of today (Union Square in NYC and the waterfront markets in Seattle) and perhaps you'll be writing a success story soon. If not, try and try again. It took time to do it, hopefully it will take less to undo it. Thanks for taking the lead Walmart.

"...tipping motivates people who work long, busy hours catering to the needs of others. It's the best way to ensure optimal service..." By this logic anyone who works long, busy hours catering to the needs of others should be tipped. Tip the doctor. Tip the grocery clerk. Tip the airline counter agent. Tip the airline pilot. Etc. I fail to see why those whose particular service happens to be delivering plates of food warrant their own method of compensation. One that puts an onus of extra calculation and deliberation on every single customer, every time they sit down to eat and relax. Thankfully, most other services in this world are one-price to the customer. It's left to the employer to do the work of assessing whether the employee is providing good service.

"It makes little sense to single out universities from among philanthropies" Hear, hear! Tax them all. There is no excuse for the continuing charade of "nonprofit" status. Everyone should participate in the tax system, and the distortions of tax free status eliminated. The authors allege that not much money is at stake, but the fact is the Congress doesn't even calculate the forgone revenue from tax free endowments. The endowments have so much political muscle, they've been able to avoid the taint of "tax expenditure" for their investment income, keeping the issue off the Congressional radar.

I couldn't agree more, that parents should have a choice. it's america after all. HOWEVER, the school districts then must be allowed to reject the attendance of those unvaccinated students. Let the anti-vaxers start their own private schools that their children can attend, and die from preventable diseases to their hearts content. (and although that is cruel, it is only cruel because that is exactly what will happen to them!)

So the only other option than the status quo is 1979? I don't buy it. I was on an airline yesterday, there was no room for my 6'3" frame and my client won't cover 1st class. There needs to be minimum seating standards, and there needs to be a trigger to require the airlines to waive baggage fees if TSA lines are longer than 45 minutes. The airlines were quick with their hands out after 9/11, they won't lift a hand now that they are fat and happy. Some regulation sounds good to me. It doesn't mean Communism, it means common sense.

Totally agree on difference between perks and policies. To me policies are super important to both my own morale and my actual productivity. A lot of policies are counter-productive in stupid ways. That makes me miserable because I WANT to be productive and do a good job. Anything that prevents this, especially from my own team, is super frustrating. Such a waste.

Genes belong to the human race and other species. They should never be patented, owned or controlled by companies or governments or individuals. They belong in the public domain. They belong to everyone. They should never be used for profitable purposes. Margaret Nwton, MD

This is a wonderful article. I have had 3 births, the first 2 were in the hospital, and my 3rd was at home. I had awful experiences in the hospital with feeling like my freedom was taken away. I felt like I was shackled to the bed from the moment I walked in. My home birth was by far the best decision I have ever made. The experience is almost indescribable. Don't get me wrong, my first 2 births are special to me only because it was the moment my beautiful children came into this world. I just wish I knew then what I know now. With my home birth, I had an absolutely wonderful midwife who monitored me, but also aloud me to have control and let my body do what it was meant to do: give birth. Pregnancy is not a sickness, and I refuse to allow it to be treated as such.

Having loved the skill, energy and movement in the pro game since seeing Wilt in an exhibition at the Garden in 1959 (when I was seven), why not first try these easier remedies to make each player more accountable: move the three point line back; stop the carrying while dribbling; get rid of the zone; and start calling giving two shots and the ball for deliberately hard fouls and not just excessively hard fouls; except in the fourth quarter, when all fouls become shooting fouls. The game in the 1960's and 1970's was a better quality game than the junk basketball that now prevails during the regular season. Oh yes: make a winning record on the road during the regular season much more significant.

As a psychiatrist who treats depression, especially severe depression, I agree with all the pleas, such as that by Ashley from UK, to use absolutely everything to help those who suffer from this awful condition: diet, exercise, meditation, CBT, group therapy, supplements, yoga, acupuncture, religion or voodoo. And yes, medication. Many are only minimally helped, some not at all, but also many are rendered completely symptom free by medications. The brain, ill or not, is mysterious, but the suffering that can dwell there can be profound. Yes, give me Prozac for the patients it will help, and all the newest over-hyped meds like Viibryd and Brintellix as well, and whatever else can be concocted. Let the doubters come sit with me for one day face to face with the darkness.

"The sentiment is right: Home schooling parents shouldn't have to pay for schools they don't use then pay again for education they do." The sentiment is completely wrong. Everyone should pay for education because everyone benefits from an educated population. I have no children in school today, but when I need a nurse or doctor in 30 years where will they come from if not from children my tax dollars are educating today? The question of how best to achieve high quality schools is another debate entirely. But the need for them is irrefutable.

If lawmakers don't (can't) recognize the contributions librarians make to the endless need for researching good answeres to questions that arise in all arenas of life, no wonder our politicians are so lame-brained loser-lunkheads. I want lawmakers to have close ties to competent research librarians. I want lawmakers to research, seriously research, the matters they vote on. Without librarians providing RELIABLE data, a lawmaker is voting based on guess, bias and campaign donations.

Don't make the school day longer. Shorten the working hours for parents -- especially where both parents have jobs -- and let the parents spend more time with their children. The parental influence on children is the most important in their development and in their education. Besides, children need time to have fun -- just to be kids.

The average teacher may have one at most two classes on children's or young adult literature. Many that I have met have an extremely shallow knowledge of this category of learning. In contrast librarians have a tremendous base of knowledge that guides not just students but the teachers within a school. Beyond the love books and knowledge librarians empower students to go beyond google, they help students learn differentiate and validate information in the sea of misinformation that characterizes the internet today. Yes teachers and schools can stumble on without a librarian, but it is as if we would ask a child to each McDonalds for a meal everyday. Their education is ultimately nutrient diminished.

There should be no exeptions from vaccinations with the exception of valid medical exemptions i.e. an individual with a serious allergy to the vaccine for example an egg alergy in the case of the flu vaccine. Asside from that demonstratable allergy no exemptions for either personal belief or religion should be entertained. If I had my way vaccinations would be a part of a single payer national health system providing universal care. The private sector has proved itself to be incompetent to provide modern health care and need to step asside.

the fact of the matter is it is our decision as parents to make the decision we feel best suits our children. if one chooses to vaccinate, that is their choice and i respect that they've made the difficult decision to protect their family by vaccinating. my choice however is to not vaccinate our children, as i feel i would be doing more harm to them than good. it's not an easy answer whichever you choose, but i am proud to be born in a country that allows me the freedom to make decisions regarding this. we as parents have researched the options fully, and are aware of both sides risks...and choose the lesser of the 2 evils for us.

I agree it will be a useful tool, to deport them. First identify all the people who have ignored the immigration laws of the US and then quietly deport them so they can be reunited with their families back in their country of origin.

Our son , already a member of the Florida Bar, was studying to take Massachusetts bar exam using materials from one of the more respected prep schools. I accepted his challenge to take the closed book exam and he was amazed when he graded my answer sheet and found that I scored with a high passing grade. Sure, I have an engineering degree and have spent many years in business and government but zero time in law school. My logic may be flawed, but I came away believing that law school is mostly a scheme to collect incredible amounts of money from students, their families and their futures to pay faculty members. This position is supported by practicing attorneys who want to create barriers and limit competition. The guild systems produced society's skilled craftsmen for centuries. Instead of the sterile halls of academe prospective lawyers should repair to the law offices of practicing attorneys. Abraham Lincoln never went to law schools. He simply read the law.

I wish people be positive about innovating solutions like these for cars. We have to start somewhere! This invention might have it's flaws but so did the first car and the first airplane and so on. We have to give inventions of this matter a chance, so we can survive the scary thought of contaminating the atmosphere of our lovely planet. I love breathing, but I also love breathing clean wonderful fresh air. Don't you?

full disclosure: I own a Jetta TDI that aside, I can go along with the premise that our business environment is already heavily regulated--I live and die with building codes and construction permitting officials. and I would agree with the assertion that another telephone book's worth of regs would not have deterred VW's deliberate and diabolical circumvention of well established regs. I could also go along with industry having a very important voice in the framing of regulations. But where, Mr Adams--where, pray tell, does it follow that "businesses are...best equipped to regulate themselves?" Your syllogism is lacking a critical premise.

Vaccines are like motorcycle helmets, they protect. Some bikers say their freedom is being curtailed by having to wear a helmet. Well when a biker gets in a crash without a helmet and has serious brain damage - society will pay dearly for letting him have his freedom. Brain damaged individuals can cost society hundreds of thousands of dollar at a minimum. A drive by shooting victim can cost us over $1 million per day. The same is true for an outbreak of measels. The attempts to eliminate polio by the world continues because the costs are obvious. When in the Navy one of the officers on my ship belonged to a religious group that would not take injections. The Navy being very pragmatic discharged him with an administrative discharge - no harm done to anyone. Anyway we are part of an integrated society and public health is important to all. Public health nursing is woefully underfunded with the simple act of providing pre-natal care, a huge amount of resources and anguish can be avoided.

I thoroughly agree with Betsy Landers that "Parents who are monitoring their children's activities via technology are not crossing the line into invasion of privacy; they are cyber-savvy and involved." As the highly cyber-savvy father of two teenaged daughters who loathe any 'invasion into their privacy', I consider it my responsibility to help them keep themselves safe. I (thankfully) have limited control over what my daughters do when out of my sight. Were that not the case, they might never make enough mistakes to learn from and grow into adults. However, we know from psychology and medicine that human beings do not fully develop their 'executive functions' until well into their late teens or early twenties. As such, they remain vulnerable to predatory influences via cybernetic technology. Granting children untrammeled freedom in the cybernetic world represents, at least in my eyes, abrogating my responsibilities as my daughters' father. Someone's got to be the adult in the parent-child dynamic, and my kids, as wonderful as they are, are not 'it'. Mark Gary Blumenthal, MD, MPH Knoxville, TN

Democracy destroys itself because it abuses its right to freedom and equality. Because it teaches its citizens to consider audacity as a right, lawlessness as a freedom, abrasive speech as equality and anarchy as progress. -Isocrates I believe in the first amendment but this man is intentionally trying to cause pain to others by disrespecting their beliefs. People will obviously be upset by this. I am upset by it and I am not a Muslim. So NO your 1st amendment rights are not violated when you are told to shut up because you are going to cause a panicked mob during a fire drill. You DON"T get to claim American rights of protection when you violate the tenets of equality and freedom in your speech.

"... the development of a ratings system is a complex and massive - but not impossible - undertaking": Well, this gets two out of three right. "I commend President Obama and his administration for tackling this difficult endeavor": Being nice to them might be a smart career move, but it isn't going to do SUNY any good. "I ... encourage my colleagues across the country to seek out an active role in the process." The administration has already told your colleagues how much it values their input; you echo that message when you write "whether we like it or not."

"Because I can do the best work of my career there." I think that constitutes fun, or at least satisfaction. Any company that PREVENTS employees from working productively, despite increasing demands upon said productivity - misery all around. I don't care about fancy gyms, I want respect and efficiency. And yes, not to drop dead at age 50 from a heart attack.

Go, Nina! After years as a vegan (and the dangerously low cholesterol levels that came with it), I couldn't agree more that humans are omnivores by design. No doubt that many of us don't get enough veggies, but that's not justification for ignoring our ancestry and anatomy/physiology. I didn't believe it until my own health suffered half way through my first year in naturopathic medical school, but there's no room for doubt now.

Lentils, whole beans, millets are great sources of B vitamins, their bioavailability increases if they are soaked overnight. Millets can even be sprouted then pound into a flour, they are gluten free. Some millets contain high amounts of calcium as well. Quinoa is another rich source of nutrition all around. As far as brain food is concerned, dairy and dairy products make up for lack of meat protein. However for stric vegans who exclude fairly products or those with lactose intolerance, meat and meat products is a good option. Being flexible is a great thing, being too strict or restrictive doesn't help anyone. Moderation is key, mix of vegetarianism, non vegetarianism is awesome, if one is willing to be flexible. Life is colorful not black and white so why limit food?

Easy access to relevant and accurate information is a cornerstone in our democracy. How can we not have specialists (aka librarians) who find, catalog, index, and protect the information used by all of us? We all frequently rely on specialists - medical, technical, financial, etc. - for the best information and advice. In this exploding universe of digital information, let's encourage our academic and governmental decision makers to fully realize the critical and specialized value that librarians provide to patrons of all ages.

In my first cubicle job, 2 people each shared a telephone that was in a hole between cubicles. A large room constructed of cinder blocks with linoleum square tiles on the floor was a zoo of ringing telephones, loud conversations and a constant stream of people walking to and fro. In my next job, I had my own private office. Hallelujah! There is no reason why workers have to be stuffed in sardine cans divided by partitions that block nothing. A windowless square is far superior to an open floor design.

Should be legal. Sex work - oldest profession - is not going away. Reduces AIDS and STDs when controlled. Half the celebrities are sex workers of sorts selling their bodies so why not the ones who actually have sex be allowed. Not everyone wants to do that. It has a strange effect on the psyche of women. An act made for bonding and love done with people you dont like - messes with the mind.

"I -... - would not support the idea if I doubted our ability to put environmental safeguards in place." Putting "environmental safeguards" in place and preventing disasters are not the same thing. Standard, well intentioned engineering practice in oil production, refining, and transport includes safeguards like double and triple redundant fail safe systems. Still, engineered systems fail and all too recently we've had well-head blowouts (Deep Water Horizon), refinery explosions and fires, and oil transport disasters ranging from pipeline ruptures to tank train derailments to the Exxon Valdez. Imagine a perfect storm situation off Virginia Beach where a well head blowout coincided with a Hurricane Sandy. Crude oil from the Chesapeake to Iceland and a potentially mortal blow to already fragile shore communities and fisheries along the way. The only way to be 100% sure that the East Coast won't suffer catastrophic damage from oil production is to outlaw the outlandishly risky exploitation of hydrocarbons in our salty ocean waters.

I am strongly inclined to assert that a thoughtfully structured program be made available to all pre-kindergarten children regardless of their family situations. I've noted that children born to upper-middle and high income parents suffer a diminished capacity to learn just as low-income children, owing to disinterested or ineffectual parenting. There will always be exceptions to the norm--the largely self-taught Abraham Lincoln, for instance. For the most part, however, it seems to make more sense to devote preventative measures whenever possible in order to improve the lives of our citizenry, thereby enriching the nation as well.

Walmart could do a public service by opening its supermarkets in the inner city ghettos. But the real health benefits will come only when folks consume a whole food based plant diet. The problem is that animal products, such as meat, fish and dairy CAUSE chronic disease. Lowering sugar, salt and fat is a start. Eliminating sugar, added salt and all animal products will result in a healthier population. Of course, if Walmart were to eliminate selling meat, dairy, soda, tobacco, alcohol, sugar, candy, junk food, etc., then nobody would shop there. Expect Walmart to get great press reviews, but disease to continue.

I attended a lecture by a PhD psychologist and former prostitute over about 40 years ago. She gave a very detailed account of the dangers faced by woman and made a very logical argument for legalization, and so treatment of sex workers as citizens whose human rights were respected. As the many replies of women in this line of work proves yet again, legalization is the answer. Also the idea represented by the statement "people are not for sale" is a completely naive and objectively false representation of reality. People sell their services and labor for the welfare, and yes, gratification of others all the time! We really need for the USA and its leaders to start acting more like Northern Europeans, in other words like rational adults that live in a world that is supposed to enlightened by reason and compassion, and science and technology.

I, too, am a liberal who is finding it harder and harder to hate Wal-Mart. First they streamlined operations, then they brought big changes to the way they heat and cool their buildings, even bringing in renewables. Then they brought their influence to bear on the farms which sell to them, requiring that they get smarter about their use of fertilizer and water (economical and environmental benefits). Now they're changing the quality of the foods they sell us, with immense implications for the nation's health and health care. All without a government mandate: conservatives should be dancing in the aisles, alongside us liberals, in encouraging such enlightened self-interest.

I'm a psychiatrist on the faculty of Johns Hopkins University, and although I now specialize in dementia I used to work heavily in addictions and chronic mental illness. Drugs of abuse and addiction tend to move in fads, fashions, and trends, and it is important for public health that doctors' training adjust to these constant changes. At this moment the trend is opioid addiction particularly prescription drugs. The trend is moving a bit back to heroin (because it's cheaper!) but prescription drug addiction is still a huge public health problem. We (doctors) created the problem (inadvertently) and we should help solve it. A brief web-based training is not too much to ask; for many doctors it will be redundant as is much of the ongoing training we are required to participate in; but it is important to spread the word widely in the medical community.

It's encouraging to read about these programs. And it's especially good to hear that along with low-income students, financial aid and other support is being given to first-generation college students. It's impossible to exaggerate the difficulties many students from these backgrounds face.

As a feminist, and a mom of a boy and a girl, I want equal opportunity for both of them. I would love to find a college beyond Wabash that's all male. Because: on average boys are doing poorly in school compared with girls. It would be even better if that all-male school encouraged the arts--everything from fine arts to domestic arts, animal husbandry, and gardening, in addition to a rigorous curriculum of reading, writing, arithmetic, and science.

We love taking our kids on vacation to foreign countries. TV and internet are just not adequate substitutes for actually being there to experience another people and culture. They learn to put up with the uncertainties and the unexpected (good or bad) that come with being in an unfamiliar environment. They learn to stay calm, to ask for help, to communicate without speaking the local language, to go with the flow and see what happens. It's great if you can afford it. One thing to keep in mind when planning a trip with kids -- Don't be too ambitious. Don't try to cover 4 cities in a week. The adults will remember the sights, but the kids will remember the frenetic packing and unpacking. So, pick a city and make it your base. Explore that city and stay a while. If you have time, make day trips.

A cat living in the wild needs its claws for climbing trees and for self defense. A pet cat kept indoors does not need its claws. If I have to keep a pet cat I would insist on declawing it. Otherwise I would forgo the pleasure of having a cat as a pet, no matter how cuddly.

Electric cars have been a long time coming. Now that Solar pannels have become more more popular we will see the increase of electric cars productivity. It's really common sense: solar panels will absorb the energy into batteries which will forever provide electricity to run these cars. It's time!!! the sun power is always there even on cloudy days!!! I only wish I could convert my 2003 Nissan into an electric car. Could that be possible? Solar pannels will forever make us independent.

I agree with this only because the fees really are not explained well in the contracts, and are usually just one or two lines somewhere around page 18 of the agreement. These fees can ruin someone who doesn't know that he's over the limit. I have a friend who had to pay several hundred dollars in fees just because he and his wife made a few little purchases over a few days without realizing that they didn't have the money in their account. For someone making $2500 a month, $35 per transaction is a huge expense. I think what would fix the problem, though, is just not allowing banks to report nonpayment of checking account fees to credit bureaus.

Playing Varsity Lacrosse in college saved me. It was the very best thing I could have done. It kept me focused, gave me a great group of friends, challenged me both physically and mentally, taught me a lot about trust and teamwork and propelled me through school. It was an incredible outlet for my energy and competitive spirt. I still to this day, believe many of my personal and professional strengths were developed by playing sports. The NCAA, without a doubt, needs to change. There is far too much money spent around the NCAA and the culture at top levels can be nasty and unattractive. But that doesn't that mean that Varsity Sports should be cut from colleges and that Varsity athletes should be punished. The NCAA needs reform as a whole-- sports need to be taken off the peddle stool that they currently stand on. But the importance of sports for many shouldn't be forgotten-- it is just as important as the arts and academia. The debate shouldn't be if varsity sports should be cut-- but how to reform the NCAA so that all schools can keep varsity sports without spending so much money.

This will be awesome, like the Model T Ford- a car that the people who employed making it can also afford to buy! Hopefully Leaf Factories will be franchised into mid-sized cities across the US. If so, Nissan will be in front of Toyota and Honda within 3 years. If they can get the price point below $15k, they'll sell 50 million of them.

I've noted that children born to upper-middle and high income parents suffer a diminished capacity to learn just as low-income children, owing to disinterested or ineffectual parenting. There will always be exceptions to the norm--the largely self-taught Abraham Lincoln, for instance. For the most part, however, it seems to make more sense to devote preventative measures whenever possible in order to improve the lives of our citizenry, thereby enriching the nation as well.

I agree that once an obligation to Society has been made by serving the penalty assessed at trial, the felon should be restored to full citizenship. Having said that I would add a period of time, say five years of good behavior after release from prison, before voting rights are restored. There should be a burden of proof that a felon must endure to prove that he or she can be a good citizen once again before voting rights can be exercised. This can only be done after the felon has been back in free society for some time.

EVERYONE uses public education. Do home-schoolers only patronize home-schooled plumbers, or nurses, or telephone repairpersons? Public education makes possible what we all live with in this Res Publica. Private education is a step back to the 17th century. Mexico is a good example of where the no-tax, limited government crowd wants to go. Having lived in Mexico for four years, where public education is severely underfunded and anyone who expects to get ahead is determined to use private education, I can attest to the benefits of a good putlic education system.

I agree with the comments that Taiwan is a democracy now, and that the US needs to side with democracy in Asia. China is by all accounts still very undemocratic and is fighting the tail end of a Civil War with the Chinese Nationalists with which Taiwan had very little to do, but Taiwan's future as a free and democratic nation is now being held hostage to that Civil War. The US needs to not only make the required defense articles available to Taiwan (this helps the US economy), but also retain its forward presence so it can come to the defense of Taiwan if push comes to shove. Another thing the US can do is to gr4adually move towards normalization of relations with Taiwan, and bring it into the international community as a full and equal member. In the 1950s and 1960s we made the mistake of isolating China. Now we are making the mistake of letting Taiwan dangle in diplomatic isolation. The people in Taiwan deserve better from us.

There should be no exeptions from vaccinations with the exception of valid medical exemptions i.e. an individual with a serious allergy to the vaccine for example an egg alergy in the case of the flu vaccine. Asside from that demonstratable allergy no exemptions for either personal belief or religion should be entertained. If I had my way vaccinations would be a part of a single payer national health system providing universal care. The private sector has proved itself to be incompetent to provide modern health care and need to step asside.

I live in Florida which makes it very difficult to restore civil rights to felons. The laws have become a new form of Jim Crow to prevent minorities from voting. Your chance of becoming a felon is much greater if you are dark of skin hue. Or a different ethnicity than being a WASP. Time to end this persecution of people We need to reform our justice system.. After release all voting rights should be restored . If a non violent conviction even the right to own fire arms should be restored.

Lentils, whole beans, millets are great sources of B vitamins, their bioavailability increases if they are soaked overnight. Millets can even be sprouted then pound into a flour, they are gluten free. Some millets contain high amounts of calcium as well. Quinoa is another rich source of nutrition all around. As far as brain food is concerned, dairy and dairy products make up for lack of meat protein. However for stric vegans who exclude fairly products or those with lactose intolerance, meat and meat products is a good option. Being flexible is a great thing, being too strict or restrictive doesn't help anyone. Moderation is key, mix of vegetarianism, non vegetarianism is awesome, if one is willing to be flexible. Life is colorful not black and white so why limit food?

Battle Hymn of a Feminist Mom: schoolwork doesn't always come first because things are often learned outside the classroom, an A- is a terrific grade, the kids are where they are in Math not 2 years ahead, activities only to win a medal? Pshaw! Failure is a necessary experience. (See Silicon Valley) But.... disrespect women, gays and people from communities of color?...then the warrior hammer comes down.

My understanding is that college athletic teams were started to teach leadership, discipline and teamwork to students. With the introduction of the athletic scholarship schools went down the slippery slope of bringing in kids who either were not prepared to do collegiate work or had no serious intent of gaining a degree. Instead of being a benefit to the academic student body, athletics became something more geared toward the fan in the stands and the alumni association- students be damned. What Spelman has done is right in so many ways. The new program will benefit all students, will open new friendships among students and will give students valuable training in how to maintain a healthy body for a lifetime. Truth be told, intramural athletics can provide the same benefits to the student body as varsity and can engage many more students at a far lower price. The fitness program is wonderful.

I tend to be a loyal consumer. I do due diligence before beginning a commercial relationship, but then I expect that the companies with whom I do business will treat me with equity and respect. I recently received notification from a bank that I have had accounts in for more than 20 years. I have always had at least one paycheck being direct deposited, I have had 2 or three savings accounts, auto loans, and investment accounts. I have always played by their rules, but the interest paid on savings dwindled to next to nothing (.03%) while charges, fees, and penalties have ballooned. The final straw came a couple of weeks ago when a whole new list of fees came out. Not only are they going to charge for paper statements (I went paperless years ago), but they are going to charge for online access! And they are going to charge $5/month for savings accounts that don't have automatic deposits going to them. Enough is enough! I am switching to a credit union.

Having worked at a college library its readily apparent Information Literacy should not be taken for granted and its fairly evident that kids going to into college haven't had enough contact with their school librarians already. There is a strange misapprehension that information is truly just a Google away and students are turning in papers based on Wikipedia entries alone. It will be a very sorry mistake to continue to view librarians as dispensable when they are so desperately needed to navigate the information explosion. As we have more and different types of tsunamis of information, we need more technologically advanced librarians to get us through it. I would also point out that as information is digitized, it falls into the hands of fewer and fewer brokers in a position to control it. The usually forgotten role of the librarian is as a bulwark against that flow of information being in some way hampered or repressed.

The best part of collet age voters is that they have nothing to steal, but feel that they deserve what the old people have worked to earn. Fortunately, we become more conservative as we get older and have contributed something real to the community, otherwise the our party would have run off the rails long ago.

Democracy destroys itself because it abuses its right to freedom and equality. Because it teaches its citizens to consider audacity as a right, lawlessness as a freedom, abrasive speech as equality and anarchy as progress. -Isocrates I believe in the first amendment but this man is intentionally trying to cause pain to others by disrespecting their beliefs. People will obviously be upset by this. I am upset by it and I am not a Muslim. So NO your 1st amendment rights are not violated when you are told to shut up because you are going to cause a panicked mob during a fire drill. You DON"T get to claim American rights of protection when you violate the tenets of equality and freedom in your speech.

We cannot depend on private industry to instantly know the best way to intervene in a disaster. There are problems that normal businesses simply don't prepare for - being cut off from supplies, having to work with only the employees that are able to show up, keeping track of things with no computers. This is what FEMA is FOR. They plan for this. They rehearse. They have experience with prior situations, and learn from each one what worked and what didn't. Why should communities re-invent the wheel? FEMA knows how to tap the local resources and guide them in how best to help. There HAS to be a centralized command structure so you don't end up with 25 truckloads of drinking water and no food. Do they always get everything right? Of course not. But I'll take my chances with an experienced crew over even the best intentions of someone trying to figure things out as they go.

the fact of the matter is it is our decision as parents to make the decision we feel best suits our children. if one chooses to vaccinate, that is their choice and i respect that they've made the difficult decision to protect their family by vaccinating. my choice however is to not vaccinate our children, as i feel i would be doing more harm to them than good. it's not an easy answer whichever you choose, but i am proud to be born in a country that allows me the freedom to make decisions regarding this. we as parents have researched the options fully, and are aware of both sides risks...and choose the lesser of the 2 evils for us.

The first are broad patents on isolated DNA sequences, which cover the gene in something very close to its natural form. " This is an example of something that shouldn't happen. What the body creates, even if someone extracts it, shouldn't be patentable. The DNA sequence is there for anyone to find with the proper technology. It's like picking fruit off the tree and saying I've "discovered" fruit. This is crazy, but then we know that the ROBBER COURT will back business to the hilt. The Supremes are now one big legal joke, and I hope in the future we can manage to pass some legislation to limit SCOTUS judges to 10 years or less. Perhaps the term length of the president that offers them up for sale.

I currently have no children in the public schools yet I am taxed for them. Should I as a taxpayer get a subsidy because I do not make use of the public schools? No. If as a society we feel that public education is important and you as a parent want to make the choice to either homeschool your children or send them to private school that is your right. However, you do not have the right to take public funds to do that. This is just a backdoor way to say that vochers are ok and to undermine funding for public schools. Public schools have to take everyone and often for special needs children at great cost. Any attempt to divert dollars away from that public good should not even be considered.

Anything that can be biologically grown and then consumed in America - should stay in America, while resisting imports on farm products that form core products in the American food market; to protect against disease, preserve FDA standards, and preserve our food market from being export dependent but if the experts are correct that the Government is not properly distributing Farm subsidies - where certain crops, in comparison to the whole American Farming system, are given more money than what is needed to support them - then the Farm Subsidy program needs to be shut down and rebuilt to reflect the actual areas that do need support. As much preserving the American domestic food market, it has to be balanced properly in response to the Federal deficit, in order to properly protect and fund America's farms.

Conservatives make me laugh when they struggle to keep their kids from learning evolution. What they're going to end up doing is keeping their children from having careers in science. Since I'm a liberal, that doesn't sound too bad to me. It keeps the competition down. People who don't accept evolution don't belong in science anyways. The more you cut out of your child's curriculum, the bigger the educational and career advantages you're handing to those kids whose parents aren't as nearly controlling and obsessive and ideologically blinkered as you are. So there is a free market solution to this problem. Maybe the Cato Institute should study that angle before they issue their next statement on the topic.

Some of my best students--bright, knowledgeable, committed--wanted to teach for America. I advised them against it. They did not have experience. Schools deserve the best teachers possible, especially in challenging schools. Being a good and effective teacher requires years of training and then continuing education,, not just in one's subject, but also in pedagogy, didactics, classroom management, organization, etc. Other countries train teachers much better and longer: they have years of specialized course work and then up to two years of assistant teaching. It pays off. Like the structural inequality that finances schools through property taxes, teacher training in the US is vastly uneven and thus perpetuates social inequality and hinders economic progress. We need uniform standards across states, equal funding for all schools, and a better education for educators.

The subsidy programs need to be reformed, not eliminated. Tighter income/subsidy caps are needed. Programs that encourage innovation instead of requiring farmers to maintain subsidized acreages and surplus production. If we use black-and-white thinking and eliminate the entire program, the largest corporate farms will benefit. The smaller farms cannot compete against the cost efficiencies that come with scale. The health of our farms is important. Our farmers are stewards of our agricultural soils, arguably our most valuable natural resource. Let's not play politics with our land. Thoughtful reform instead of knee-jerk reactions to a system plagued with problems.

Income is income and should be taxed as the least harmful of all taxes. Eliminate property tax, but tax all income at the same graduated rates. Currently, there is no benefit in savings with interest rates at .3%. Investors should be encouraged to invest in capital projects or improvements, or donate to philanthropic groups by taxing idle income.

As a dual citizen of The United States and Bulgaria,i strongly feel that it is a benifit. I did not want to lose my allegiance to my mother country, however i also wanted to take advantage of all the wonderful oppertunities this country has to offer because they were not available to me back home. Its a privelage that should not be taken advantage of.

Age 17, my son had intolerable stomach pain in the middle of the night. He visited web MD, concluded he might have appendicitis, woke me up at 2 AM, and suggested we go to the hospital for possible appendix issue. He is not a complainer, so I took him at his word. Result: appendix removed at 7 AM. I'm a believer.

What's next? Childless families get the tax break? Those whose children go to private schools get a tax break? Do we get the tax break when our children finish schoo? We ALL have a vested interest in a well educated population. We all have an obligation to contribute to the public school system.

There would be very little difference in the price of fruits and vegetables if the farmers paid a reasonable wage. They'd need to do it together to not harm each other in the food market, that's what the unions and cooperatives are for. And we really need to license the labor contractors. So that they lose their licenses if they don't provide adequate water and toilets to workers in the fields. No farmer wants a dead worker featured in their harvest. It brings a farmer's competency into question among the community. Mostly, farmers who pay less than good wages are megafarms and cheaters. They like illegal aliens because they can unload the costs associated with hiring workers onto the neighboring communities. And because these workers are less likely to know and object when they are being exposed to pesticides or abuse.
